text: I was you both shall live they tied the
knot as soon as they could the
Australian MP Stephen Dawson and his
partner Dennis little Oh got married on
Saturday let Stephen and Dennis are now
married it was the first opportunity to
do so since the Australian Capital
Territory passed a law allowing gay
marriage in Canberra and its surrounding
area around 30 ceremonies have taken
place in the past five days
but now the High Court has overturned
the law and all of the unions will be
declared invalid this is personally
devastating unless in less than a week
we've been married and we've been
unmarried at least on a legal level as
one of the absolutely beautiful couples
behind me said we're still married I've
made commitments to Chris to spend the
rest of my life with him Paul suggests
that around a third of Australians
oppose gay marriage the Prime Minister
Tony Abbott is one of them and his
government challenged the new law it
said it contravenes federal law which
defines marriage as between a man and a
woman the court agreed and said same-sex
marriage is a matter for Parliament not
state and territory authorities last
year Parliament's voted against a bill
to make gay marriage legal some
campaigners say this case represents
progress although there's been a defeat
for marriage equality in the High Court
today this week we've seen a much
greater victory and that victory was
that the nation saw for the first time I
believe what is really at the core of
this issue we've seen that marriage
equality is not about protests or
politics or even about laws and the
Constitution ultimately
marriage equality is about love
commitment family and fairness without
you by my side but for those who took
advantage of the brief window when gay
marriage was legal in Canberra the
honeymoon has been short-lived Emily
Thomas BBC news
